sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) and standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the decomposition reaction of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) at 298 K:

CaCO3(s) → CaO(s) + CO2(g)
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) and standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the decomposition reaction of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) at 298 K, we need to use the standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) and standard molar entropies (S°) of the substances involved in the reaction.

The standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) for the substances are as follows:
CaCO3(s): -1206.9 kJ/mol
CaO(s): -635.1 kJ/mol
CO2(g): -393.5 kJ/mol

The standard molar entropies (S°) for the substances are as follows:
CaCO3(s): 92.9 J/mol·K
CaO(s): 39.8 J/mol·K
CO2(g): 213.8 J/mol·K

Now, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction using the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ [ΔHf°(products)] - Σ [ΔHf°(reactants)]

ΔH° = [(-635.1 kJ/mol) + (-393.5 kJ/mol)] - [(-1206.9 kJ/mol)]
ΔH° = (-1028.6 kJ/mol) - (-1206.9 kJ/mol)
ΔH° = 178.3 kJ/mol

Next, we can calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction using the following equation:

ΔS° = Σ [S°(products)] - Σ [S°(reactants)]

ΔS° = [(39.8 J/mol·K) + (213.8 J/mol·K)] - [(92.9 J/mol·K)]
ΔS° = (253.6 J/mol·K) - (92.9 J/mol·K)
ΔS° = 160.7 J/mol·K

So, the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the decomposition reaction of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) at 298 K is 178.3 kJ/mol, and the standard entropy change (ΔS°) is 160.7 J/mol·K.
